text: Post-“Girls,” Zosia Mamet stars in “The Flight Attendant,” an HBO Max mystery series, and spends quality time with her six-year-old mare. “I’ve always been a horse girl,” she says. https://t.co/hFfcnaffRA

text: The singer-songwriter-whistler-violinist Andrew Bird will live-stream his annual holiday concert from California this year. “I’m going to string up some café lights and do it at sunset,” he said.  https://t.co/OXwD53ddwt

text: Has a desire to protect children put their long-term well-being at stake? “My biggest concern is that we’re going to lose these kids,” one teacher says. “They might never come back.” https://t.co/L7GA4RI5xE

text: .@nicolatwilley on the sugar industry’s race to not just develop a substitute for sugar, but to design a better sugar altogether. https://t.co/NcXisDLBzW

text: Under any circumstances, putting medicine into glass vials is a tricky business. Getting COVID-19 vaccines out will require more than a billion vials to be manufactured, ﬁlled, and shipped, at top speed and in some cases under extreme stress. https://t.co/EQsay2X4qL

name: NewYorker
text: “Whatever the work is, do it well—not for the boss but for yourself.” Toni Morrison on the lessons about work, and life, that she learned from her father. https://t.co/uGpSWMyseN

name: NewYorker
text: Larissa MacFarquhar discusses what happens to families in Haredi Jewish communities when one parent leaves the faith. Custody cases "can get incredibly contentious and traumatic," she says. https://t.co/i2Bp1rjBKp

name: NewYorker
text: Improbable things seem to happen to Patrick Byrne, the founder of Overstock, with remarkable frequency. But Bryne’s critics say his beliefs about a deep-state plot have gone too far. https://t.co/kFVGNe3pxF

name: NewYorker
text: We might not have realized how going to the office lent our daily lives a sense of occasion, but, seeing Stanley and Jim putting on their coats and scarves and trudging out the door, we do, @asarahlarson writes. https://t.co/KtWzesfWTa

name: NewYorker
text: In gentrifying neighborhoods, empty houses are sitting ducks. For cheap security, real-estate companies hire the homeless to guard expensive properties. The rules are simple: don’t host guests, don’t talk to anyone, and don’t leave. https://t.co/5hdbikqaA0

name: NewYorker
text: The last words in Shirley Jackson's journal, written six months before she died, are: “I am the captain of my fate. Laughter is possible laughter is possible laughter is possible.” https://t.co/wZPXq48c9N

name: NewYorker
text: “A Teacher” wishes to splash cold, purifying water on a permitted perversion, a subject of memes and giddy Post headlines: the sexual abuse of boys and young men by women. https://t.co/6ABbK5mkRv

name: NewYorker
text:
In “Paradise Lost,” John Milton’s burning question—how things could have gone so wrong in human affairs—is carried back to the story of Adam and Eve. But the author, born on this day in 1608, was also a deep defender of human dignity.
https://t.co/Bb9w8Ds5yY

name: NewYorker
text: What makes “The Queen’s Gambit” so satisfying comes in large measure from Anya Taylor-Joy's character: a charming, elegant weirdo who delivers her lines with a cool, wintergreen snap, @rachsyme writes. https://t.co/cAA2FvVqH1

name: NewYorker
text: Alt-right conspiracy theorists think that the government killed the aspiring Libertarian filmmaker David Crowley. The truth is far stranger. https://t.co/zasXMCWSn5
